reviewText:
Based on the reviews, I was expecting a really badly made game. However, I was somewhat surprised. Sure, Alpha Prime is nothing extraordinary, but it's not crap by any means either.

It's a standard corridor FPS with a story. If you like FPS games, there is nothing to complain about here, aside from perhaps the difficulty being a bit too high. I've played on Easy and even then some sections were unusually hard and caused me to die many times.

The story isn't bad either. Again, it's nothing groundbreaking, but for an FPS game it's pretty decent. Most FPS games don't make anywhere near the effort in the story department as Alpha Prime does. The cutscenes and the radio dialogue sections between the characters were a nice addition to keep the game interesting. Most characters were developed reasonably well in terms of personality.

The graphics are very nice. Considering the game came out in 2007, those are pretty decent visuals, even by today's standards. The music is also not bad. There are only about 1 or 2 jarring heavy rock tracks, but the rest of the soundtrack is pretty good and gives a nice epic feel to the battles.

The enemy variety could've certainly used some work. You spend a good 80% of the game just fighting spec ops, which gets repetitive eventually. There are some other gameplay sections added too, like hacking, and using a loader to move boxes out of the way, which is a nice change of pace, even if some sections were quite annoying. The loader in particular was difficult to control, and having to move a dozen of boxes out of the way just felt like a waste of time.

In general the game is not as bad as the reviews claim it to be. It's just a standard, above average FPS that will keep you entertained for a few hours. If you are into the genre, give it a try, otherwise pass it up.

reviewText:
I figured I'd write a review in case you have some spare coins and are looking for a cheap game.

I've played through this twice so I know this game and some of it's problems.
In short: This game feels like a mod for Doom 3.

First off, the game is really linear and doesn't sport much exploration. There are a few exceptions; secrets and alternative routes. Good level design helps very much in this regard as each area feels pretty well thought out and assets doesn't feel overly repeated.

I thought level design was pretty good. What messes things up is the scripted stuff. I.E take the wrong route, the jump-scare-enemy bugs out and crashes your game... twice.. or until you enter the room through the expected entrance. If you spot enemies and shoot them from afar, an elevator might not come down because the enemies the were scripted to use it and bring it down, thus, you'll have to reload to an earlier savegame.
Unfortunately, stuff like this screws the game up badly. Use quick-saves often.

This game is pretty weak on the story, which is delivered by some of the absolute worst voice actors I've heard. There are no exceptions. In fact, it's so bad it gets good. Ironic as it is, I laughed through the cut-scenes. Not much of it makes sense. Theese things, though unintentionally, serves as a comical break between game-play. It just feels funny.. for some reason. Brilliance in it's own, accidental way.

Difficulty wise, the game is schizophrenic. You'll have a complete breeze throughout the first third of the game. Braindead A.I. This gets compensated as the soldiers appear. It's not easy any more. The difficulty suddenly sky-rockets through the roof. It's braindead A.I but with pinpoint accuracy. Regardless, it's a challenge.

This game also features a hack system. You can hack surveillance cams, turretguns and locked doors to reach secret areas.
Hacking is really only required once, and that is to open a door. Everything else is solvable without it.

Vehicle sections in this game is bad. You'll want to get them over with as soon as possible. Thankfully you won't have to do it much.

Alpha Prime is not a game with a limited two-weapon system, you can actually carry the entire arsenal. However, you are most likely to use the assault rifle.. It's way too overpowered compared to the other weapons.
You'll only use the sniper rifle when the distance requires a scope, otherwise the assault rifle is about as accurate, holds more rounds and fires more rapidly.
In close quarters, you'd normally favour a shotgun, but a two shot burst with the assault rifle is just as good and ammunition is plentiful.
The use of explosives is rarely ever called for, and in those situations, they are so unreliable you might be better off with the assault rifle even in these situations.
Lastly, the embarrassing axe that leaves bullet-hole decals on walls. It fires as fast as you can click your mouse button. It's completely broken. Luckily, you'll never ever find use for it. It's exists just for the sake of it.

In terms of graphics, this game can't compete with the mainstream contemporaries of it's time (which would be Bioshock or ... Crysis). Rather, this game looks like a bright Doom 3, which means it looked dated even at release. But as this game is old and has a low pricetag, that shouldn't matter now.

Sound assets works. Nothing really special to mention here. None of the weapon-sounds makes them feel punchy enough, but the overall ambience is doing it's job rather well.

So, overall, this game looks and feels like a non-scary Doom 3 mod. It's kind of a B-graded game that certainly has it's problems. But if you are ready to overlook that and just take it for what it is, (a game that's actually cheaper than a subway sandwich) you might have good time with it. I know I had.
I like it for what it is.

Cheers!

reviewText:
Is this game worth the full asking price?  No, probably not.
There's simply too many other, better games out there to be had for the same price.

Is this game fun? Sure it has it's moments. At times it feels more like a strategy game than a straightforward shooter.
At no time in this game can you do anything even resembling what is shown in the videos above, as far as running around jumping at enemies throwing grenades and shooting rampantly. You will always be low on HP, and low on ammo. The enemies always shoot first and they never but rarely ever miss. Most of them take 8-10 shots to the face to kill, and they come in groups.

The weapons are frustratingly bad.
Others here have mentioned how incredibly terrible the shotgun is, and I agree, for a game anyhow.
Most FPS players are used to an overpowered unrealistic shotgun. In the MW and COD games you are using a rifled barreled fully choked military grade weapon. In this game, the shotgun is basically a sawed off shotgun from a seedy pawn shop. Surprisingly is shoots very similar to a real sawed off shotgun, but that doesn't mean it should ever have been put into the game this way. You'll need to be no farther than about 15 feet from your target if you hope to even hit it. About 6 feet if you hope to kill anything. It's just frustrating. Especially since the game keeps giving you ammo for the damn thing, over and over and no ammo for the assault rifle, which itself is pretty underpowered.  I found myself going for my pistol, over the shotgun, because the pistol is so overpowered compared even to the AR that it's kind of silly. Too bad you rarely get any ammo for it.

The best gun in the game by far in my opinion in the sniper rifle. Though throughout the entire game, you'll only get about 40 rounds for the thing, and all but the lowest enemies require 2 or 3 shots to the face to kill with it. Why is it my favorite? I don't know, I guess it's the only one of the weapons that almost felt like it was done right.

The grenades are a joke. You can toss one 4 feet from a guy, and he won't even go into the damage animation.
You literally have to hope the grenade lands at his feet, preferably ON his feet if you want him to die.

I suppose I should mention there is a Flamethrower, a Rocket Launcher, and a Hammer for a melee weapon.
No real reason to mention them though.
On several occasions I hit an guy in the face with a rocket, and he didn't even care. I'm sure it did some damage, but it's comical to see such a huge explosion, and out of the fire and smoke the guy is still shooting at you.

The Flamethrower has the range of a hairspray can lit with a lighter. It's sometimes funny to watch the flame thrower enemies shooting flame at you from 8 feet away and you not taking damage. It's not so funny when you're the one using it though. Also it's comically underpowered. A complete botch of a weapon and no surprise, there's plenty of ammo to be found for it. The game also hides the damn things in secret rooms, as if it's some super weapon you'd actually want to use.

The Hammer is your melee weapon.
It's so pathetic that it even exists that it's hard for me to find words as to describe why it's even in the game.
Enemies shoot you with unmissable headshots from hundreds of yards away, and the game gives you a frigging hammer.
Do I even need to mention it's uselessly underpowered?

The levels are passable. They are strictly linear affairs, which isn't uncommon. The amount of unused and useless rooms was probably meant to give the game some feeling of depth, but to me it just felt unfinished.

The platforming parts of the game are stupid. This game should not have them. The jumping is beyond bad. Your legs are made of glass, because if you fall or jump from more than about 6 feet you will die. I'm no badass weapon weilding space marine like this guy but I've somehow managed to survive jumping off the side of a pickup truck. That would be death for the hero of this game.

The physics in the game are annoying. Throughout the game, most things you grab will fall through the floor, or go into a frenetic jiggle spazm until it flies across the room, only to then sink into the floor when it comes to a rest.

It was kind of cool to have to take the lid off of boxes to see what was inside though. Unfortunately of the hundreds of boxes in this game, only about 10 have anything in them. Which lead me to beleive the location for the game is a facility to mine and store Empty Boxes.

There's an F5 quicksave feature that eventually becomes so necessary that you become glad it doesn't take but a second or two for it to save. I found myself killing one enemy, hitting save, killing another, hitting save, etc.

So why am I giving this game a thumbs up?
Truthfully, it's a bad game, but I had fun in spite of myself.
Plus there's 90% off Steam coupons to be had which means you can experience the pain of this game yourself for only 50 cents. It's hard to pass up anything for that price.
If nothing else, you can have the experience of what an FPS game is like when you do nearly everything wrong in making it.

reviewText:
Alpha Prime is a Sci-Fi FPS based on a space station (a mine for a rare, new mineral called habardium.. or something) which has suffered an accident and on which there are only a handful of survivors. You have been sent in at the behest of your ex in order to save their current husband to be from the station.

The game plays somewhat like an inferior Fear, having sci-fi weaponry and the ability to slow down time for a short while, but the guns in the game feel very underpowered. The assault rifle is the only weapon that is of any worth - the sniper rifle, shotgun and pistol doing practically no damage and being inferior in every situation to just tap shooting from the assault rifle. For 10 rounds you can kill an enemy which may take a second or two, but two shotgun blasts will take perhaps double that - and the shotgun is only able to be used at close range, where your health will vanish pretty quickly.

The game is pretty unforgiving in some places with the combat. Your slow motion doesn't recharge on it's own and requires the mineral harbidudmidmm (you know, the mineral that's being mined on the station that you're turning into your own battlezone) and a single enemy, unchecked, can easily kill you. Additionally, ammunition for the assault rifle is pretty hard to find, even though it drops off of the enemies that you kill, meaning that a tight spot might grow tighter.

The game has aged to a far greater degree than Fear, whilst the Unreal 2 engine's physics and lighting standards are still adequete enough, the physics in this game leave much to be desired. Ragdolls seem to go through objects sometimes and get stuck in them, the ground is often littered with random objects which you can easily get snagged on and the lighting seems hardly like a step up on DOOM.

TL;DR it sucks

reviewText:
First let me say I somewhat enjoy this game and everything written below is not meant as negative criticism.
This game is a standard budget FPS with lame plot and dumb yet unforgiving enemies.  You are John Prime (or whatever his name is) who is lured by his ex to save her current boyfriend from what can only be described as the biggest cluster♥♥♥♥ of trouble ever. Yep , stuck on a mining planet with a bunch of crazed miners and hostile robots. And then the corporation owning the mine sends swat teams to clean up the mess (you included).

Gameplay is pretty standard- you've got your shotgun , machinegun , sniper and stuff. Oh , and bullet time. Bullet time is pretty much useless , cause unlike other games that use a slowing time mechanic , here your bullets and you get slowed down the same amount as the enemies. You know how in Max Payne you trigger bullet time while falling so you gently soar like an oak leaf in October , but you still can aim with almost the same speed as outside bullet time , and your bullets travel a little bit faster than the enemy's. Well you wont see that in Alpha prime. In bullet time you move and shoot just as slow as your enemies , you still aim at normal speed , but it seems the AI does too. What you can , and should use are the lean buttons. Yep , [Q] and [E] are going to be your best buds again after all these years (ok you might have used E for Use , its bound to F now). I have found that you take 5-10 times less damage if leaning compared to popping out using A/D. Your health does not regenerate , but there are med kits and med stations (a-la Half Life/Jedi Knight) scattered around.

Oh , also , dont let the screenshots fool you - the game has 1080p

In conclusion: OK game if you like generic FPS , can be a little unforgiving at times , but the first few levels have more than enough med kits.

Also , I read someones review , that said objectives pop up for a few seconds and then you cant check them afterwards. Not true - you need to hold down the Z key (redefineable , I use TAB)

reviewText:
This game isn't complete crap... but it's still pretty bad

That being said, the first thing I noticed was the graphics, they ain't bad playas. Looks like a DOOM 3 clone of some sort. The overuse of bloom is very prevalent but for under 1GB it's surprisingly good looking.

The story is awful.

The voice-acting will have you begging for your mama's buttermilk pancakes. It's bad... really, really, bad.

While you're slogging through the 3 hour long campaign, you'll begin to question your sanity of why you're still playing this game. It gave me high hopes when I received a hammer as my first weapon. Who doesn't like bopping people in the head with such hardware? You get your standard pistol, machine gun with a low capacity clip, Sniper rifle with a semi-interesting scope, A Rocket Launcher with ZERO splash damage, A shotgun that is inconsistent on the damage front & a hilariously bad looking flamethrower.

At one point you get to play basketball. This really let's the game's physics engine shine. You will NEVER get the basketball in the hoop. In fact, you can actually be murdered by the basketball. There's a point in the game where you get to drive around in a buggy. It's another terrible experience.

Every time an enemy fires their gun... you get hit. They're expert marksmen. This game doesn't feature regenerating health, instead you get medkits & medical apparatuses on walls. You can't take much damage on any difficulty. It's frustratingly bad, the gunplay is bad, you don't feel like you can win any firefight triumphantly. You WILL be hit for big chunks of damage no matter what. Alpha Prime does try to execute a really poor slowdown effect that leaves you unsatisfied. Gunplay as a whole is just a mess.

The game constantly crashed while loading the next levels.

Please don't play this game. Even if it's 29 cents, it's not worth your time. Don't be like me, don't expose yourself to it.

reviewText: Surprisingly fun, despite the voice acting being almost offensively bad. On easy it's a hell of a challenge, but on hard, you'll become good friends with the floor from all the times you drop dead onto it. Robots that had competent programmers and soldiers that don't wander around like it's Night of the Living Derp mean that you have to take your time and think about how to approach the situation given to you. There's a nice range of weapons, each with some sort of useful application, and the hacking cam mode is a nice feature, if a little unchallenging. The ability to lean and peer around objects and walls is an incredibly useful addition, and very nicely done. At around 5-6 hours, it's unsatisfyingly short, but a fun ride while it lasts. Dig the spare change out of your sofa and buy it, it's worth every last cent.

reviewText:
Alpha Prime is a fairly interesting game, it's a sci-fi FPS that takes elements from games such as Doom 3 and Quake 4 (Even the aesthetic of the game will remind you of them) and implements some of its own little things here and there. At first it does seem cliche and it kind of is but players will soon find that there is a very slight supernatural element to the game that affects the psyche of all the people surrounding Alpha Prime, turning them into deranged madmen and making the base's AI go nuts and the Corporation is on clean up duty. Your job is to save your friend who's stranded on Alpha Prime.

Unlike most shooters that take a more old school approach (health packs, hip fire, carrying a full arsenal, etc), on normal difficulty the enemies hit very hard which will require you to take a more tactical approach to combat situations which will encourage you to use the lean function as well as the remote control mechanic, allowing you to hack into devices such as cameras, gun turrets, doors and other electronic devices. So since that little introduction is out of the way, now I'll start the review and first I'll break it down into lists of pros and cons to make this review a lot more straight forward:

Pros:
- Fun and solid gunplay
- Nice visual effects
- Cool art style
- Graphics still look good even today
- No regenerating health, all done with medkits and health stations
- You can fire from the hip (Always good to have)
- Characters have a bit of personality to them
- Level design is pretty good
- The soundtrack is just awesome
- Enemy AI are quite intelligent, always seeking cover, trying to outsmart and outgun you whenever possible and will rush you when they have the chance
- A nice array of weapons to use (A gatling-based assault rifle is pretty awesome)
- The remote control is cool and fun to use, turning gun turrets against your foes is always fun
- Very challenging, will crush gamers who are used to modern FPS and regenerating health

Cons:
- The story could have been really cool but it was fairly bland and the cliffhanger didn't help either
- Bullet time and flamethrower are near enough useless except for the last boss
- Enemy placement can be very cheap at times making the difficulty feel very artificial
- Enemy variety is near enough non-existant, just different guys with different guns and some robots
- Weapons given to the player have pretty poor pacing, it gives you every gun near enough from the get go
- The remote control mechanic is too underutilized, you'll often forget you have it later in the game
- Voice acting can be pretty atrocious sometimes
- The one vehicle segment is just awful, it controls like crap and you can't even run enemies over with it
- Enemies have pinpoint accuracy to the point where it's unfair at times (And you can't even dodge their shots in bullet time, yes it's that useless)
- Some character models look creepy, making the main character look like a plastic action figure
- Cutscenes and dialogue segments go on for WAY too long and when you need to do something, you can't pause them but thankfully they can be skipped
- The game only runs for the best part of 4 hours, for a single player only game that will be far too short for most

The game has a lot of flaws, but it's nowhere near as incompetent like games such as The Stalin Subway and Dusk 12 (Which I did enjoy somewhat). It's not awful by any stretch, some people will love what Black Element did with the game, others may not. It really comes down to a matter of opinion and my opinion is that I really enjoyed it, as short as it was, it was a fun little sci-fi romp with lots of action, somewhat interesting characters and cool aesthetic. It's a shame the remote control was barely ever used and the game was very unbalanced at times but it was a fun game to play as the afternoon or evening just wizzes by.

I do recommend this game to those who enjoyed old school shooters or for those who will enjoy something that makes players take a more tactical approach to their combat strategy, for me the positives outweigh the negatives and since I'm a sap for obscure FPS games, there is a chance I will like it for it's quirk. For those who prefer modern FPS with highly linear levels and the overuse of iron sights and regenerating health then this really isn't for you. But if you like kickass FPS soundtracks then this game is great to have, it has some truly fantastic music in there that just gets you really pumped for the action, big kudos to the composer! I'll wrap this up now though, it's on sale now for £0.59 or your regional equivalent and that will give 4 hours of great sci-fi action. I'd say it's worth picking up.

I will say this; Don't buy this game. It turned me off within twenty minutes, and I usually have a really decent tolerance for games that others dislike. In all honesty, I'll put down a list of Pros and Cons to help you understand why.

I sincerely hope this is not the end product, or even close. The idea sounds somewhat neat, but there are a lot of things needed to be done before i ever consider this again; Until then, I want my forty nine cents back.

reviewText: It's the decent action flick b-list movie of sci-fi fps gaming, if you know what you're getting into it's entertaining enough to keep playing. The story is not particularly interesting but the game doesn't really bore you with details of it to warrant a criticism in this regard. The graphics, although dated, haven't aged particularly badly and the game has enough visual settings to crank up to the max and any mid-range modern graphics card won't even break a sweat to give you more than enough fps with it.\n\nCutscenes are a blast, but I'm sure it's not for the intended reasons, gives the otherwise bland and non crucial story line a dose of warmth. Gameplay is somewhat repetitive and it might tend to get boring if you're having to play a level from the start again, because you died and forgot to save your progress along the way. Overall, if you have some time to kill waiting for the next big AAA title and you don't want to spend much money, get this game (preferably on sale) and have some fun blasting aimlessly at the enemies. reviewText:
I got this as part of some Humble Bundle, and at one point, I played it. And even though this game really suffers from an inherent lack of polish, I found myself really wanting to like this game. It bring some solid concepts forward to the table as a shooter, such as the hacking interface. It's sort of like Watchdogs as an FPS with this; scan security cameras to check enemy locations and numbers, set up environmental hazards up for remote detonated traps, and even use some of the machinery for surprise attacks. It has good ideas... BUT...

There's a lot wrong with this game. On a presentation scale, it's easily the worst part about the game. For a game released in '07, it looks like it comes from '02, and really doesn't have a lot of the aged visuals that can still look good in the modern day with games like, for instance, Unreal Tournament '99. The voice acting is atrociously bad, though it sounds more like bad localization and English dubs, and a lot of the sound quality is atrocious.

Gunplay is enjoyable, and some of the weapon designs like the gatling rifle and the sniper rifle are appealing, but the difficulty is extremely harsh, and the AI is pretty unforgiving. Even with patches to fix this, it still does put a damper on the gameplay as a whole.

So, I still do find myself really wanting to like this. It's a decently interesting package that does seem appealing, but suffers from some serious issues that drag it down hard. There are definitely other games out there more worth your money, but if it shows up in a good Humble Bundle or something, maybe give it a gander.

reviewText: It's the decent action flick b-list movie of sci-fi fps gaming, if you know what you're getting into it's entertaining enough to keep playing. The story is not particularly interesting but the game doesn't really bore you with details of it to warrant a criticism in this regard. Gameplay is somewhat repetitive and it might tend to get boring if you're having to play a level from the start again, because you died and forgot to save your progress along the way. Overall, if you have some time to kill waiting for the next big AAA title and you don't want to spend much money, get this game (preferably on sale) and have some fun blasting aimlessly at the enemies. There is not much replay value for the game and the graphics engine is outdated, meaning there won't be no wow factor, so take that into consideration before purchasing this game.

reviewText: Alpha Prime is generic and uninspired in every aspect.  Shooting, action, environments, sound design, voice acting, writing... all as plain and unmemorable as you can possibly get.  I used ridiculous-looking and wildly underpowered weapons to shoot the exact same spaceman commando" character models inside of the same dark space station corridors over and over again.  I stopped occasionally for a couple of bigger set piece moments and once for an awkward
date: floaty jaunt across the planet's surface in a vehicle that is definitely NOT the Mako (wink wink).  I tried to kill people with grenades that don't actually kill people.  I fought a 2 minute boss battle that uses the same "shoot him until he gets into the thing to recover his health and then hack the machine to kill him" mechanic that I've seen a dozen times before.  I sat impatiently through long dialogues of contrived nonsense that did nothing but interrupt the flow of the game and left me more confused than before.  Not dreadful so much as thuddingly uninspired and incoherent.  Possibly worth a quick 5-6 hour playthrough if you can get it for a dollar or less but in this age of virtually unlimited gaming options for low prices
recommended: you're better off almost anywhere else."
